page.title: 10FARMING ON THE LONGMYND
page.content: Farming in this part of{Shropshire is mainly confined to{dairy cattle}and {sheep rearing.} The{Longmynd}itself rises to over 1400 feet and temperatures are at least 10 deg.C lower than{Dorrington in the valley.Upland mist covers these hills for many days of the year making everything wet. Winters are severe with over twenty-five days of snow a year. The soil in the region is generally poor and shallow and the ground is very rocky in places.Because of the altitude the growing season is roughly two weeks later than farms down in the valley.Sheep rustling is also a problem for farmers on top of the Longmynd. The main crops that the farmers grow are{barley}and{hay}which are used to feed the cattle.
